title: Storage Vessel (Mulondo)

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of blackened terracotta.

artist_display:
Songye
Democratic Republic of the Congo
Central Africa
description: Writing in 1905 and 1906, the German ethnographer Leo Frobenius praised Songye pottery, attributing to it a "plainly astonishing beauty and a copious but measurable abundance of forms." Indeed Frobenius recorded over two hundred different types of Songye pots, many of which were variations on the tall-necked storage container. This container is embellished in a characteristically robust style, with deeply incised lines that emphasize the neck and shoulders. The chain of arches appear tightly controlled, as do the grooves around the neck, and the arches at mid-neck have been squared off. According to Frobenius, much of this kind of embellishment is added to a pot when it is still wet, while finer details are incised after it is leather hard. The surface is overlaid with a dense, crusty coating interrupted by areas of high sheen that suggest age and use. A dry yellow substance coats the interior base and lower walls of this container, perhaps to help make it watertight. [See also 2005.252].
credit_line: African and Amerindian Art Purchase Fund
publication_history:
Douglas Dawson Gallery, African Ceramics:  Ancient and Historic Earthenware Vessels (Chicago: Douglas Dawson Gallery, 1993), pp. 32 (ill.).

Kathleen Bickford Berzock, For Hearth and Altar: African Ceramics from the Keith Achepohl Collection (The Art Institute and Yale University Press, 2005), pp. 161-162 (ill.).
exhibition_history:
Chicago, Ill., Columbia College Art Gallery, Spirits and Spouses: Gender Roles in African Art, Feb. 12-Apr. 5, 1996, no cat.

Art Institute of Chicago, Women's Work:  African Terracotta Vessels,  July 26-Sept. 14, 1997, no cat.

Art Institute of Chicago, For Hearth and Altar: African Ceramics from the Keith Achepohl Collection, Dec. 3, 2005-Feb. 20, 2006, cat. 100.
provenance_text: Thomas Alexander, Alexander Gallery, St. Louis, Mo., by 1995; sold to Douglas Dawson Gallery, Chicago, Ill., by 1995; sold to Keith Achepohl, Iowa City, Iowa, 1995; given to the Art Institute, 1995.
